item.title: The Men Behind the Cartoons at Charlie Hebdo
item.description: According to those who knew them and followed their work, the four cartoonists who were killed Wednesday represented a radical, crude and vital strain of French culture.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: World Briefing: China: North Korean Soldier Dies
item.description: A North Korean soldier who fled into China and killed four Chinese citizens in late December has died after being injured during an arrest attempt by Chinese security forces, according to reports by Chinese state news organizations.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Two Brothers Suspected in Killings Were Known to French Intelligence Services
item.description: The slaughter raised questions about how Chérif Kouachi, so well-known to the police for so many years, and his brother managed to conceal their intentions.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Cherif Kouachi, left, 32, and his brother, Said Kouachi, 34, who are suspected in a deadly attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris.

item.title: Monterrey Journal: A Bus Takes a Local Route to Fighting Mexican Corruption
item.description: Born through a mix of frustration, satire and savvy, the Corruptour is a free one-hour ride led by young activists hoping to stir a political awakening with five trips per weekend.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Corruptour bus, which visits sites linked to corruption in Monterrey, Mexico, is decorated with caricatures of politicians.

item.title: One Suspect Surrenders in Attack on French Newspaper; Two Others at Large
item.description: Hamyd Mourad, 18, suspected in an assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, walked into a police station northeast of Paris and gave himself up. The other suspects are two brothers, Said and Chérif Kouachi.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Cherif Kouachi, left, 32, and his brother, Said Kouachi, 34, who are suspected in a deadly attack on a satirical newspaper in Paris.

item.title: World Briefing: Gambia: Ex-Head of Guards Led Coup Attempt, Government Says
item.description: Gambia’s government accused a former head of its presidential guard on Wednesday of leading an attempt last week to oust President Yahya Jammeh.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Shell Agrees to Pay $83.5 Million for Oil Spills
item.description: The oil giant Shell agreed early Wednesday to pay a Nigerian fishing community ending a three-year legal battle in Britain over two spills in 2008 that destroyed mangroves and seafood that had sustained Bodo villagers.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Merkel’s Visit to Britain Sets New Tone After E.U. Rift
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron hoped that Chancellor Angela Merkel would help him mollify those in his party who clamor for an exit from the European Union, something both leaders said they are eager to avoid.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, center, and Prime Minister David Cameron in London on Wednesday, where they held a summit meeting.

item.title: ‘Dangerous Moment’ for Europe, as Fear and Resentment Grow
item.description: The strike against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo seems certain to accelerate the growth of anti-Islamic sentiment in Europe.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: The mood among Parisians near the scene of the attack Wednesday on the newspaper Charlie Hebdo was apprehensive and angry. “There’s no respect for human life,” said Annette Gerhard.

item.title: F.B.I. Says Little Doubt North Korea Hit Sony
item.description: Instead of routing their attacks through decoy servers, the hackers sent them directly from web addresses in North Korea, the F.B.I. said. But some skeptics still wanted to see the agency’s evidence.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, NICOLE PERLROTH and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN.
item.media:credit: Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times
item.media:description: "They used proxy servers to disguise” the trail of evidence, Mr. Comey said. “But sometimes they got sloppy.”

item.title: Violence Grows in Yemen as Al Qaeda Tries to Fight Its Way Back
item.description: Houthi fighters seized control of the Yemeni capital of Sana in September, promising radical political reforms, but the hope is crumbling.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Houthi militiamen stood guard on a wall surrounding the old city of Sana last Thursday, preparing for a celebration of the birth of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: News: Latest Updates on Paris Shooting
item.description: New York Times reporters are providing live updates from the deadly shooting at a satirical newspaper in Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A screenshot of an image posted on Instagram on Wednesday by Elsa Wolinski, whose father, Georges Wolinski, was killed in Wednesday's attack.

item.title: Ruth Popkin, President of Hadassah Who Worked to Resettle Refugees in Israel, Dies at 101
item.description: Ms. Popkin, the former president of Hadassah, the Jewish National Fund and the World Zionist Congress, assisted immigrants and environmental projects in Israel.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK
item.media:description: Ruth Popkin, who led Jewish causes, in an undated photo.

item.title: Weather Makes Bad Situation Worse for Syrian Refugees
item.description: A fierce winter storm has compounded the misery of the millions of Syrians displaced by their country’s civil war and left the organizations that seek to help them scrambling to keep up.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Syrians in a refugee camp in eastern Lebanon prepare to remove the snow threatening the stability of their tents on Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Uganda: Military Confirms Surrender of L.R.A. Commander
item.description: Uganda’s military said Wednesday that it had confirmed that a man who turned himself in to American troops was indeed Dominic Ongwen, a senior commander of the Lord’s Resistance Army.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Court Condemns American’s Kidnapper to Death
item.description: An Antiterrorism Court in Lahore sentenced Hafiz Imran to death on Wednesday in the kidnapping of the American aid worker Warren Weinstein.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILANI

item.title: World Briefing: New Zealand: All Plunge to Safety as Skydiving Plane’s Engine Quits
item.description: All 13 people aboard a New Zealand skydiving plane whose engine apparently failed Wednesday managed to leap out in parachutes moments before the plane plunged into a lake, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Attack on Charlie Hebdo and the Tradition of Parisian Wit
item.description: Charlie Hebdo’s editors started as aggressively secular youth rebels.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HUSSEY

item.title: Stéphane Charbonnier, Known as Charb, Relished Defying Mores
item.description: Stéphane Charbonnier, editor of the satirical weekly who was killed in an attack on the newspaper’s offices Wednesday, was instrumental in a series of defiant campaigns.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: Stéphane Charbonnier, the editorial director of the satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo, spoke to reporters in Paris in 2012.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Is Skeptical of Nuclear Talks With U.S.
item.description: Saying that the United States could not be trusted to lift sanctions, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said that Iran should find internal solutions to economic problems.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Supreme Leader, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Speaking at his residence in Tehran on Wednesday, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran, said that the United States could not be trusted to lift sanctions.
